THE NE S LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. M.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 30, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

SOPHOMORES WIN MEET

BASEBALL PRACTICE STARTS

NO ALUMNI LACROSSE TEAM

EDITORS START TO WORK

Defeat Freshmen by a Margin of Ten
Points—Novak and Catlin the
Individual Stars.

Candidates Gather in Cage and Hear
Speeches from Coach and Advisers—
An Ambitious Schedule.

Announcement Made by Mr. W. C.
Schmeisser and G. Pitts Raleigh,
Advisers of the 'Varsity.

The "Hullabaloo" Will Be a Certainty
If the Students Support It—
Editorial Plans.

The annual inter-class track team,
'held Saturday afternoon in the
• cage, was won by the sophomores
by a score of 391
/
2 to 292 points.
The meet, however, was much
closer than the score indicates and
it was not until the last event—the
pole vault—was completed. that
the result was certain, and, in faGt
at one time the freshmen were 8
points ahead.
Catlin and Novak were the individual stars, each landing two firsts.
Pieper's work in the 30-yard finals
was also creditable, as he equaled
the record for the Hopkins "cage."

At a well-attended baseball massmeeting held last Wednesday afternoon in the trophy room of the
"cage," the plans for the nine for
the coming season were outlined by
Coach Hooper, Captain Pieper,
Manager Sattler, Drs. Magoffin
and Abercrombie, and President
Holmes of the Athletic Association.
A great deal of enthusiasm was
shown and everything points to a
very successful team.
Coach Hooper made a short,
snappy address, which contained
some very helpful suggestions for
the prospective candidates. He
emphasized the fact that the players
would have to work hard every
moment that they are on the
diamond. He made an appeal for
candidates ,with "pepper" in their
make-up, as this is the herb he has
found in the most successful baseball players.
Captain Pieper issued a call for
candidates, and a large proportion
of those present at the massmeetMg signified their intention of
coming out for the team by signing the paper that was passed
around for the signatures of the
candidates. Manager Sattler said
that he wanted all those who joined
the squad to stick to it during the
entire season, as a large squad was
absolutely essential for the success
of the team. A strong "scrub"
team will be organized for those
who do not make the first nine.
Dr. Magoffin, a veteran of
several Hopkins baseball teams "in
the good old days," said a few
words of encouragement to the
players and congratulated them on
their efforts in again securing recognition for baseball from the Athletic Association. He expressed a
'wish that the baseball team would
make as great a reputation for itself
as the other Hopkins 'varsity athletic teams have been making
during the past few years.
Dr. Abercrombie gave those preseht some pointers about training,and
what would be expected of the
players. Although this is the first
nine for a number of years, Dr.
Abercrombie said that preparations
were being made for it on a larger
scale than for any of those in the
past. "Johnny" Holmes said that
it was up to the team this year to
make good, and that if they did
they would be backed in every way
by the students.
The initial practice for the squad
of candidates will be held next

To the surprise of most Of the
students, announcement was made
last week by the alumni advisers
of the lacrosse team that there will
be no alumni team this year. This
news was made public in a letter
from the advisers, Messrs. Wm.
C. Schmeisser and G. Pitts Raleigh.
In the letter it is stated that the
chief reason for coming to the
decision is the state of our relations
with Nit. Washington. In past
seasons games have been played
between the 'varsity and Mt. Washington, and a spirit of intense
rivalry has arisen, and, in some
instances, hard feeling has been en(rendered. For this reason the advisers of the lacrosse team recommended that there be no game
between Mt. Washington and the
'varsity this year, with a view to
smoothing over the differences.
This decision has resulted in an
enormous amount of opposition and
complaint on the part of the supporters of Mt. Washington, and
it was thought that the maintenance
of an alumni lacrosse team this year
would only increase the hard feeling. It has, therefore, been definitely announced that no alumni
team will be put on the field this
year.
This will leave Mt. Washington
and Hopkins 'varsity the only two
teams in the city. The Hopkins
schedule is solely an intercollegiate
one, but Mt. Washington has arranged games with a number of
fast out-of-town aggregations. It is
probable that their ranks will be
recruited from the Hopkins alumni,
and that the club will try to put on
the field one of the best lacrosse
teams they have had for a number of years.

Work on the Hopkins "Hullabaloo" has at last been commenced
in real earnest by the board of editors and it looks, for the first time
since the announcement of the
failure of last year's juniors to publish the book, as if the University
would have a creditable annual this
year.
The senior section of the joint
board of twelve men, has a lot of
material all ready, and in shape to
be sent to the printer just as soon
as the contracts are signed. The
juniors also have much work done,
and have thought out some original
ideas which they will incorporate
in their section of the book. About
half of the pictures of the men in
the two classes have been taken.
Nearly all the seniors had their
faces catalogued last year, and a
committee of the board is to make
arrangements with the photographer this week to have the rest
taken.
If the book is to come out, it
is absolutely imperative that all the
material be ready by the first of
March, with the exception, of
course, of a few late items, such as
the lacrosse season, the debate results, and the baseball team. This
will mean that all of the pictures
will have to be taken, the grinds,
the roasts and biographies written,
and all the so-called "humorous"
Matter prepared in a month.
Finances just at present seem
to be in a brighter condition than
they were a month ago. The Glee
and Instrumental Clubs have promised to give a concert and dance
for the benefit of the "Hullabaloo,"
and the proceeds from this ought to
be considerable. This may be held
in Lehman's Hall or possibly, if
the authorities permit, in McCoy
Hall, and the money which would
have to be paid for Lehman's will
be saved.
Then, • a committee is making
plans for an amateur night in the
"cage." There is a great deal of
vaudeville talent among the students, but outside of some memorable courses, there has never been
an adequate opportunity afforded to
develop it. Stockett, Ben Tappan,
H. C. Burgan, Bill Haynes and a
host of others, ought to be able
to afford an evening of pleasure to
the students at popular prices, and
besides the good .time which all
would have, there would 'be some
funds contributed to the year-book
treasury.

Dr. Mead to Lecture.

Dr. Edwin D. Mead, director of
the newly-formed School of International Peace, and one of the most
distinguished advocates of international arbitratiop, will deliver a
lecture at 5 o'clock, Tuesday afternoon, under the auspices of the
Arbitration Society.
Dr. Mead's subject will be "The
United States and the United
WOrld." He is an attractive speaker and has lectured in nearly every
State in the _Union.
The 'lecture Will be given in the
Donovan Room. The .public is invited.

BALTIMORE, M D., JAN. 30, 1911.

Again after a long silence we
invoke the powers that be. The
postmaster has too many functions.
There are times of the day when
this individual has to attend to
three or four different things at a
time. It is true that the cloak-room
does not keep one man busy all
the time, but the postoffice does,
and it is too much to ask a man
to attend to both these things at
once. Now someone must be neglected, either the man waiting at the
postoffice window or the one with
check in hand expecting his coat
and hat. Much time is lost at
present and a better arrangement
would be welcomed.

It occurs to us to ask how many
persons apply for the government
positions, announcements concerning which are continually being
posted. The requirements to be
met are so great and the emolument in most cases is so small that
it does not seem as though many
would be interested.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 30, 1911

RARE MEDIAEVAL ANTIQUES
Old Religious Works to Be Found in
New York Museums-Valuable
Collection of Mr. Morgan.
By GEORGE C. KEIDEL, Ph. D.

The fervent religious belief of
the Middle Ages found material
expression in Western'Europe in
many forms, and modern times
have inherited innumerable beautiful specimens of Medieval handiwork connected in some way with
the church.
On a recent visit to New York
it was my privilege to be able to
inspect quite a number of such art
objects in various public and private collections, and it is a pleasure
to give the following description of
a few of these interesting remains
of an age long past:
THE LIBRARY OF MR. J. PIERPONT
MORGAN
Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan, the
noted New York financier, has been
engaged for some years past in
accumulating books, manuscripts,
paintings and tapestries of priceless
value from the point of view of
the enthusiastic collector that he is.
Many of these he has given or
deposited in various public institutions, but perhaps the choicest of
them he has housed in his own
private library on Madison avenue
in New York.
Only recently he acquired a
wonderful manuscript Apocalypse
of Spanish workmanship, dating
from the Middle Ages. The
text is in Latin and is, of
course, of moderate length; but
the voluminous commentary and
the many large miniatures have
but the voluminous commentary
and the many large miniatures have
swelled the size of the parchment
volume to quite considerable proportions. This beautiful volume is
heavily ornamented with silver
trimmings on the exterior of the
Lying on a stand there was also
seen a fine specimen of the famous
Mazarine Bible published in Germany soon after the art of printing was invented. Bibliophiles have
given this name to it by common
consent, simply because Cardinal
Mazarin, of 'France, once possessed a copy which came prominently into notice many years ago.
This Bible is a very thick volume
printed in the heavy old-fashioned
Gothic type, and it is a notable
triumph of the printer's skill.

THE HISPANIC MUSEUM
Mr. Archer M. Huntington, the
son of the late railroad magnate
Collis P. Huntington, is an enthusiastic collector of art objects and
literary works pertaining to Spain.
A few years ago he founded and
endowed the Hispanic Society of
America, whose permanent home
in New York is the Hispanic
Museum, a beautiful building on
the heights overlooking theHudson.
The skillfully carved portal of
an old Spanish monastery is here
installed in state, where its beautiful marble work charms all visitors.
This interesting relic of the Middle
Ages presents in material form a
reminder of the religious fervor
which found expression in Spain in
the Inquisition, that far-famed tribunal of the Church.
Richly embroidered vestments
and altar cloths were displayed on
a series of folding panels, and
many hundreds of photographs of
churches and other buildings of a
religious character were at hand for
the purpose of giving a vivid
picture of Spanish architecture.
THE UNION THEOLOGICAL
SEMINARY
This well-known institution of
learning has only recently occupied
a very large and imposing structure
of granite erected in the Oxford
Gothic style of architecture in the
northern section of New York,
where it offers religious training
to students of all denominations
that may yield to its attractions of
many sorts.
Amongst the many rare and
valuable religious works in the
library there was found a fifteenth
century edition of the Summa
Prodicantium by Johannes Bromiardus, an English theologian of the
fourteenth century who wrote a
number of voluminous works. The
compilation cited above contains
some five thousand stories related
in a condensed form and intended
to be used by Medkeval preachers
as illustrative material for their
sermons.
The same library also contains
an old edition of the Scala Ccli of
Johannes Junior, a German monk
who composed a similar work only
a few years after the English theologian had written his treatise.
The few instances just cited may
be taken to illustrate the fact that
whereas New York was formerly a
place of business and business
only, it has now become attractive
to the student also because of the
great progress being made by its
colleges and its libraries, which are
supplemented in a wonderful way
by the resources placed at the
limited disposal of the public by its
ihany wealthy collectors.

BOOK REVIEW

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES

The Interest of America in International Conditions. By A. T. Mahan:
Boston: Little, Brown & Company.
Price, $1.50 net.

What the Embryo Doctors Are Doing—
"Heart Station" Installed in Physiological Laboratory.

There are four essays in the
latest book of Captain Mahan, and
although he does not give any facts
which are not known to students
of international affairs, or attempt
to advocate some pet policy, his
summaries are very enlightening
and have all the purpose and effect
of criticism.
He says that the United States
is intimately concerned in international politics; that she has acted
in consultation with the European
community of States many times
in matters "in which they and
we have interests, like, yet independent." This is called a confession that the Monroe Doctrine
can no longer be accepted as
supreme in the relations of this
country to European States.
The most important policy which
the author assigns to the United
States is the preservation of the
open door." Little is said about
Secretary Knox's much criticised
proposal to internationalize the
railways in Manchuria, but it can
be inferred that Captain Mahan is
not at all opposed to this neutralization of the transportation facilities.
He is in favor, therefore, of what
would be a practically permanent
international occupation of Manchuria. So long as Japan and
Russia abide by the provisions of
the Portsmouth treaty, this would
hardly be necessary, but says the
author, "There can be no question
that the general recent attitude
of Russia and Japan, however
laudably meant, does arouse such
suspicions."

The second dance of the series
given by the Cotillion Club was
held last Saturday night, January
28th, in McCoy Hall. As is usual
with these dances, it was a most
successful affair. The assembly
room was decorated with palms,
while in the halls were hung the
class banners, making a very
pleasing ettect. Behind a screen
of palms on the platform was the
orchestra.
The dance began at half-past
eight and lasted until half-past
twelve. There were sixteen dances,
and between the eighth and ninth
a light supper was served to some
sixty people who were present.
The wives of the faculty graced
the dance with their presence as
chaperons, while several of the
faculty themselves "actively"
attended.
It is to be regretted that the
students do not arrive until late at
the dances. At both this and the
last dance there were very few
couples on the floor until the third
or fourth dance, and there seems
but little tendency to improve this
condition. Let us hope that at
the next function we will all see
the error of our ways and arrive
on time.

A great deal of popular interest
has been aroused by the installation
in the physiological laboratory ofthe
medical clinic of a "heart-station."
This is an apparatus for detecting
abnormalities in the action of the
human heart, by recording in the
form of a curve the minute "action
currents" of electricity produced by
the heart-beat.
A small outfit of this sort has
been in use in the Johns Hopkins
Hospital for a year, and the new
installment is merely a larger and
more perfect instrument.
The "action currents" of the
heart are so minute and vary so
rapidly that the ordinary galvanometer of the physicist is too
crude to record them; therefore,
the "heart-station" is equipped with
a "string-galvanometer," invented
by W. Einthoven. In this instrument a thread of platinum or
silvered quartz, 0.002 millimeters
in thickness, is suspended between
the poles of a strong magnet, and
vibrates when a current traverses
it. The vibrations are photographed on a moving film through
a microscope. In this way a current of extremely minute potential,
as short as .01 second, may be successfully recorded.
In practice the electrodes consist of pans of water, in which the
patient's hands or feet are placed.
It would be quite possible, of
course, to wire all the wards, so
that the patient would not have to
be moved, but this has not been
done as yet. Abnormal state's of
the heart are detected by comparing tile record with normal tracings.
The local "heart-station" is
under the care and direction of
Drs. Barker, Hirschfelder, and G.
S. Bond.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 30, 1911

COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

In a recent issue of THE NEWSLETTER there is mention of the fact
that some two dozen delinquent
subscribers have not paid their
subscriptions for the year 1909• 1910. It is scarcely necessary to
remark that they have not paid for
the year 1910-1911. That means
that a very considerable number
of students who signed their names
to subscription blanks have cheerfully received the paper for a year
and a half, have doubtless criticised
it freely •and frankly whenever it
seemed imperfect, and have given it
their patronage in every form except the small detail of paying
for it. As a former NEWS-LETTER
editor, I found this situation interesting enough to provoke question.
Who," I asked the business manager,are these reluctant patrons?
Men who have to count the cost?
Men who are selfishly immersed in
their own affairs and who, if those
affairs happen to be exclusively
scholastic, are called grinds? Under-classman, who may perhaps be
excused for a certain lack of college spirit?"
None of these," he replied.
t` They are chiefly upper-classmen.
Two of them have been class presidents. Others have been active
in sports. Not one is working his
way through college and not one
shows in his manner of life the
least symptom of enforced economy.'
The answer was what might have
been expected. The man who has
to count the cost usually counts it—
and pays his bills. It is the good
fellow who is always going tifpay
that brings insolvency to the business department of a college enterprise.
There are just two comments I
want to make on all this. One is for
the delinquent subscribers: That
way of doing things in college is
mighty bad training for after life.
The big world is not at all patient
with the man who put§,his name to
an obligation—particularly a financial obligation — and then lightly
neglects to fulfil it. The business
manager can doubtless testify that
such is the printer's point of view.
The second comment brings us
nearer home. Those members of
the faculty who are brought into
touch with the collegiate department pretty generally subscribe
for THE NEWS-LETTER and pay for
it. The alumni also subscribe in
far greater numbers than they did
a few years ago and pay their subscriptions. What are we to think
about the college spirit which we
are trying to foster at Hopkins
when we learn that you have to be
entreated for a year and a half to
pay a dollar and a half to the
support of your only college paper?
If THE NEWS-LETTER were a
useless institution, or a useful

institution steadily declining to an
inevitable end, there would still be
no excuse for not keeping one's
word to it. But THE NEWS-LETTER
is not declining. It is clearly on the
up-grade-. There is every reason
for encouraging the present board
of editors and for smoothing the
rocky path which the present business managers must tread. I believe that if the editors will defer
publishing the promised list of
names—which are of no interest to
anybody—and will once more bring
their claims personally home to the
unresponsive twenty-four, no list of
names will ever be necessary.

Medical School held a joint meeting in the Medical Amphitheatre on
Monday, January 23rd, Drs. Moss

was Dr. Harry, chief probation
officer of the Juvenile Court of
Baltimore, and the address concerned the work of that court.
Dr. Harry emphasized especially
the success of the parole system in
preventing first offenders from
being forced into a career of crime..
About 100 students were present.

Additions to Museum.

Valuable articles have lately been
added to the Johns Hopkins University Museum. They are lent by
Dr. Esther B. Van Deman, research associate in Rome of the
Carnegie Institution of Washington,
who delivered a lecture in McCoy
Hall last week on "Master Builders
of Ancient Rome."
Among the numerous objects lent
to the museum should be mentioned
a'fine pair of Roman bronze cymbals, the only pair in this country,
and one of the very few examples
in any museum to have the connecting bronze chain still attached.
There are also two beautiful bronze
mirrors with incised designs of
great beauty; a magnificent cistrum,
such as the Egyptian priests of
Isis used in their processions in
Rome; a number of Roman glass
bottles and vases; an etruscan funeral urn, with a so far undecipherable inscription; several large early
Roman bronze coins, Roman lamps,
and pottery of various shapes.
There are besides, several bronze
bracelets and rings, and a number
of splendid bronze fibulae or safety
pins. There are also some fine
specimens of Roman marbles and
alabasters. These articles have been
put in one of the cases of the Archeological museum on the third
floor of McCoy Hall. Dr. Van Deman is the aunt of Dr. R. V. D.
Magoffin of the department of history.
There is a precedent at Kansas
that the man who proves to be a
successful cheer leader shall retain
his position throughout his college
course. This cheer leader, besides
leading the yells, invents color
schemes to be used at the games.

The third week of the freshman
gyirnasium contest has been completed and the Whites and the
Blues are as close as they ever
were. Although several hundred
points have been scored by each
division, the totals are only about
fifteen points apart. The Blues
seem to have the individual "stars,"
while the Whites have the team
work. However, first one side and
then the other is ahead, so that the
final outcome promises to be very
exciting.
Captain Steuart White (Whites)
set for his men a pace that would
soon have left the Blues far behind

on the alert.

At a well-attended baseball massmeeting held last Wednesday afternoon in the trophy room of the
"cage," the plans for the nine for
the coming season were outlined by
Coach Hooper, Captain Pieper,
Manager Sattler, Drs. Magoffin
and Abercrombie, and President
Holmes of the Athletic Association.
A great deal of enthusiasm was
shown and everything points to a
very successful team.
Coach Hooper made a short,
snappy address, which contained
some very helpful suggestions for
the prospective candidates. He
emphasized the fact that the players
would have to work hard every
moment that they are on the
diamond. He made an appeal for
candidates ,with "pepper" in their
make-up, as this is the herb he has
found in the most successful baseball players.
Captain Pieper issued a call for
candidates, and a large proportion
of those present at the massmeetMg signified their intention of
coming out for the team by signing the paper that was passed
around for the signatures of the
candidates. Manager Sattler said
that he wanted all those who joined
the squad to stick to it during the
entire season, as a large squad was
absolutely essential for the success
of the team. A strong "scrub"
team will be organized for those
who do not make the first nine.
Dr. Magoffin, a veteran of
several Hopkins baseball teams "in
the good old days," said a few
words of encouragement to the
players and congratulated them on
their efforts in again securing recognition for baseball from the Athletic Association. He expressed a
'wish that the baseball team would
make as great a reputation for itself
as the other Hopkins 'varsity athletic teams have been making
during the past few years.
Dr. Abercrombie gave those preseht some pointers about training,and
what would be expected of the
players. Although this is the first
nine for a number of years, Dr.
Abercrombie said that preparations
were being made for it on a larger
scale than for any of those in the
past. "Johnny" Holmes said that
it was up to the team this year to
make good, and that if they did
they would be backed in every way
by the students.
The initial practice for the squad
of candidates will be held next

To the surprise of most Of the
students, announcement was made
last week by the alumni advisers
of the lacrosse team that there will
be no alumni team this year. This
news was made public in a letter
from the advisers, Messrs. Wm.
C. Schmeisser and G. Pitts Raleigh.
In the letter it is stated that the
chief reason for coming to the
decision is the state of our relations
with Nit. Washington. In past
seasons games have been played
between the 'varsity and Mt. Washington, and a spirit of intense
rivalry has arisen, and, in some
instances, hard feeling has been en(rendered. For this reason the advisers of the lacrosse team recommended that there be no game
between Mt. Washington and the
'varsity this year, with a view to
smoothing over the differences.
This decision has resulted in an
enormous amount of opposition and
complaint on the part of the supporters of Mt. Washington, and
it was thought that the maintenance
of an alumni lacrosse team this year
would only increase the hard feeling. It has, therefore, been definitely announced that no alumni
team will be put on the field this
year.
This will leave Mt. Washington
and Hopkins 'varsity the only two
teams in the city. The Hopkins
schedule is solely an intercollegiate
one, but Mt. Washington has arranged games with a number of
fast out-of-town aggregations. It is
probable that their ranks will be
recruited from the Hopkins alumni,
and that the club will try to put on
the field one of the best lacrosse
teams they have had for a number of years.

Work on the Hopkins "Hullabaloo" has at last been commenced
in real earnest by the board of editors and it looks, for the first time
since the announcement of the
failure of last year's juniors to publish the book, as if the University
would have a creditable annual this
year.
The senior section of the joint
board of twelve men, has a lot of
material all ready, and in shape to
be sent to the printer just as soon
as the contracts are signed. The
juniors also have much work done,
and have thought out some original
ideas which they will incorporate
in their section of the book. About
half of the pictures of the men in
the two classes have been taken.
Nearly all the seniors had their
faces catalogued last year, and a
committee of the board is to make
arrangements with the photographer this week to have the rest
taken.
If the book is to come out, it
is absolutely imperative that all the
material be ready by the first of
March, with the exception, of
course, of a few late items, such as
the lacrosse season, the debate results, and the baseball team. This
will mean that all of the pictures
will have to be taken, the grinds,
the roasts and biographies written,
and all the so-called "humorous"
Matter prepared in a month.
Finances just at present seem
to be in a brighter condition than
they were a month ago. The Glee
and Instrumental Clubs have promised to give a concert and dance
for the benefit of the "Hullabaloo,"
and the proceeds from this ought to
be considerable. This may be held
in Lehman's Hall or possibly, if
the authorities permit, in McCoy
Hall, and the money which would
have to be paid for Lehman's will
be saved.
Then, • a committee is making
plans for an amateur night in the
"cage." There is a great deal of
vaudeville talent among the students, but outside of some memorable courses, there has never been
an adequate opportunity afforded to
develop it. Stockett, Ben Tappan,
H. C. Burgan, Bill Haynes and a
host of others, ought to be able
to afford an evening of pleasure to
the students at popular prices, and
besides the good .time which all
would have, there would 'be some
funds contributed to the year-book
treasury.

United States and the United
WOrld." He is an attractive speaker and has lectured in nearly every
State in the _Union.
The 'lecture Will be given in the
Donovan Room. The .public is invited.

BALTIMORE, M D., JAN. 30, 1911.

Again after a long silence we
invoke the powers that be. The
postmaster has too many functions.
There are times of the day when
this individual has to attend to
three or four different things at a
time. It is true that the cloak-room
does not keep one man busy all
the time, but the postoffice does,
and it is too much to ask a man
to attend to both these things at
once. Now someone must be neglected, either the man waiting at the
postoffice window or the one with
check in hand expecting his coat
and hat. Much time is lost at
present and a better arrangement
would be welcomed.

It occurs to us to ask how many
persons apply for the government
positions, announcements concerning which are continually being
posted. The requirements to be
met are so great and the emolument in most cases is so small that
it does not seem as though many
would be interested.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 30, 1911

RARE MEDIAEVAL ANTIQUES
Old Religious Works to Be Found in
New York Museums-Valuable
Collection of Mr. Morgan.
By GEORGE C. KEIDEL, Ph. D.

The fervent religious belief of
the Middle Ages found material
expression in Western'Europe in
many forms, and modern times
have inherited innumerable beautiful specimens of Medieval handiwork connected in some way with
the church.
On a recent visit to New York
it was my privilege to be able to
inspect quite a number of such art
objects in various public and private collections, and it is a pleasure
to give the following description of
a few of these interesting remains
of an age long past:
THE LIBRARY OF MR. J. PIERPONT
MORGAN
Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan, the
noted New York financier, has been
engaged for some years past in
accumulating books, manuscripts,
paintings and tapestries of priceless
value from the point of view of
the enthusiastic collector that he is.
Many of these he has given or
deposited in various public institutions, but perhaps the choicest of
them he has housed in his own
private library on Madison avenue
in New York.
Only recently he acquired a
wonderful manuscript Apocalypse
of Spanish workmanship, dating
from the Middle Ages. The
text is in Latin and is, of
course, of moderate length; but
the voluminous commentary and
the many large miniatures have
but the voluminous commentary
and the many large miniatures have
swelled the size of the parchment
volume to quite considerable proportions. This beautiful volume is
heavily ornamented with silver
trimmings on the exterior of the
Lying on a stand there was also
seen a fine specimen of the famous
Mazarine Bible published in Germany soon after the art of printing was invented. Bibliophiles have
given this name to it by common
consent, simply because Cardinal
Mazarin, of 'France, once possessed a copy which came prominently into notice many years ago.
This Bible is a very thick volume
printed in the heavy old-fashioned
Gothic type, and it is a notable
triumph of the printer's skill.

THE HISPANIC MUSEUM
Mr. Archer M. Huntington, the
son of the late railroad magnate
Collis P. Huntington, is an enthusiastic collector of art objects and
literary works pertaining to Spain.
A few years ago he founded and
endowed the Hispanic Society of
America, whose permanent home
in New York is the Hispanic
Museum, a beautiful building on
the heights overlooking theHudson.
The skillfully carved portal of
an old Spanish monastery is here
installed in state, where its beautiful marble work charms all visitors.
This interesting relic of the Middle
Ages presents in material form a
reminder of the religious fervor
which found expression in Spain in
the Inquisition, that far-famed tribunal of the Church.
Richly embroidered vestments
and altar cloths were displayed on
a series of folding panels, and
many hundreds of photographs of
churches and other buildings of a
religious character were at hand for
the purpose of giving a vivid
picture of Spanish architecture.
THE UNION THEOLOGICAL
SEMINARY
This well-known institution of
learning has only recently occupied
a very large and imposing structure
of granite erected in the Oxford
Gothic style of architecture in the
northern section of New York,
where it offers religious training
to students of all denominations
that may yield to its attractions of
many sorts.
Amongst the many rare and
valuable religious works in the
library there was found a fifteenth
century edition of the Summa
Prodicantium by Johannes Bromiardus, an English theologian of the
fourteenth century who wrote a
number of voluminous works. The
compilation cited above contains
some five thousand stories related
in a condensed form and intended
to be used by Medkeval preachers
as illustrative material for their
sermons.
The same library also contains
an old edition of the Scala Ccli of
Johannes Junior, a German monk
who composed a similar work only
a few years after the English theologian had written his treatise.
The few instances just cited may
be taken to illustrate the fact that
whereas New York was formerly a
place of business and business
only, it has now become attractive
to the student also because of the
great progress being made by its
colleges and its libraries, which are
supplemented in a wonderful way
by the resources placed at the
limited disposal of the public by its
ihany wealthy collectors.

BOOK REVIEW

MEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES

The Interest of America in International Conditions. By A. T. Mahan:
Boston: Little, Brown & Company.
Price, $1.50 net.

What the Embryo Doctors Are Doing—
"Heart Station" Installed in Physiological Laboratory.

There are four essays in the
latest book of Captain Mahan, and
although he does not give any facts
which are not known to students
of international affairs, or attempt
to advocate some pet policy, his
summaries are very enlightening
and have all the purpose and effect
of criticism.
He says that the United States
is intimately concerned in international politics; that she has acted
in consultation with the European
community of States many times
in matters "in which they and
we have interests, like, yet independent." This is called a confession that the Monroe Doctrine
can no longer be accepted as
supreme in the relations of this
country to European States.
The most important policy which
the author assigns to the United
States is the preservation of the
open door." Little is said about
Secretary Knox's much criticised
proposal to internationalize the
railways in Manchuria, but it can
be inferred that Captain Mahan is
not at all opposed to this neutralization of the transportation facilities.
He is in favor, therefore, of what
would be a practically permanent
international occupation of Manchuria. So long as Japan and
Russia abide by the provisions of
the Portsmouth treaty, this would
hardly be necessary, but says the
author, "There can be no question
that the general recent attitude
of Russia and Japan, however
laudably meant, does arouse such
suspicions."

The second dance of the series
given by the Cotillion Club was
held last Saturday night, January
28th, in McCoy Hall. As is usual
with these dances, it was a most
successful affair. The assembly
room was decorated with palms,
while in the halls were hung the
class banners, making a very
pleasing ettect. Behind a screen
of palms on the platform was the
orchestra.
The dance began at half-past
eight and lasted until half-past
twelve. There were sixteen dances,
and between the eighth and ninth
a light supper was served to some
sixty people who were present.
The wives of the faculty graced
the dance with their presence as
chaperons, while several of the
faculty themselves "actively"
attended.
It is to be regretted that the
students do not arrive until late at
the dances. At both this and the
last dance there were very few
couples on the floor until the third
or fourth dance, and there seems
but little tendency to improve this
condition. Let us hope that at
the next function we will all see
the error of our ways and arrive
on time.

A great deal of popular interest
has been aroused by the installation
in the physiological laboratory ofthe
medical clinic of a "heart-station."
This is an apparatus for detecting
abnormalities in the action of the
human heart, by recording in the
form of a curve the minute "action
currents" of electricity produced by
the heart-beat.
A small outfit of this sort has
been in use in the Johns Hopkins
Hospital for a year, and the new
installment is merely a larger and
more perfect instrument.
The "action currents" of the
heart are so minute and vary so
rapidly that the ordinary galvanometer of the physicist is too
crude to record them; therefore,
the "heart-station" is equipped with
a "string-galvanometer," invented
by W. Einthoven. In this instrument a thread of platinum or
silvered quartz, 0.002 millimeters
in thickness, is suspended between
the poles of a strong magnet, and
vibrates when a current traverses
it. The vibrations are photographed on a moving film through
a microscope. In this way a current of extremely minute potential,
as short as .01 second, may be successfully recorded.
In practice the electrodes consist of pans of water, in which the
patient's hands or feet are placed.
It would be quite possible, of
course, to wire all the wards, so
that the patient would not have to
be moved, but this has not been
done as yet. Abnormal state's of
the heart are detected by comparing tile record with normal tracings.
The local "heart-station" is
under the care and direction of
Drs. Barker, Hirschfelder, and G.
S. Bond.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 30, 1911

COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

In a recent issue of THE NEWSLETTER there is mention of the fact
that some two dozen delinquent
subscribers have not paid their
subscriptions for the year 1909• 1910. It is scarcely necessary to
remark that they have not paid for
the year 1910-1911. That means
that a very considerable number
of students who signed their names
to subscription blanks have cheerfully received the paper for a year
and a half, have doubtless criticised
it freely •and frankly whenever it
seemed imperfect, and have given it
their patronage in every form except the small detail of paying
for it. As a former NEWS-LETTER
editor, I found this situation interesting enough to provoke question.
Who," I asked the business manager,are these reluctant patrons?
Men who have to count the cost?
Men who are selfishly immersed in
their own affairs and who, if those
affairs happen to be exclusively
scholastic, are called grinds? Under-classman, who may perhaps be
excused for a certain lack of college spirit?"
None of these," he replied.
t` They are chiefly upper-classmen.
Two of them have been class presidents. Others have been active
in sports. Not one is working his
way through college and not one
shows in his manner of life the
least symptom of enforced economy.'
The answer was what might have
been expected. The man who has
to count the cost usually counts it—
and pays his bills. It is the good
fellow who is always going tifpay
that brings insolvency to the business department of a college enterprise.
There are just two comments I
want to make on all this. One is for
the delinquent subscribers: That
way of doing things in college is
mighty bad training for after life.
The big world is not at all patient
with the man who put§,his name to
an obligation—particularly a financial obligation — and then lightly
neglects to fulfil it. The business
manager can doubtless testify that
such is the printer's point of view.
The second comment brings us
nearer home. Those members of
the faculty who are brought into
touch with the collegiate department pretty generally subscribe
for THE NEWS-LETTER and pay for
it. The alumni also subscribe in
far greater numbers than they did
a few years ago and pay their subscriptions. What are we to think
about the college spirit which we
are trying to foster at Hopkins
when we learn that you have to be
entreated for a year and a half to
pay a dollar and a half to the
support of your only college paper?
If THE NEWS-LETTER were a
useless institution, or a useful

institution steadily declining to an
inevitable end, there would still be
no excuse for not keeping one's
word to it. But THE NEWS-LETTER
is not declining. It is clearly on the
up-grade-. There is every reason
for encouraging the present board
of editors and for smoothing the
rocky path which the present business managers must tread. I believe that if the editors will defer
publishing the promised list of
names—which are of no interest to
anybody—and will once more bring
their claims personally home to the
unresponsive twenty-four, no list of
names will ever be necessary.
ALUMNUS.
The Student Boards of the FederatedCharities connected with the
Medical School held a joint meeting in the Medical Amphitheatre on
Monday, January 23rd, Drs. Moss
"and Sladen presiding. The speaker
was Dr. Harry, chief probation
officer of the Juvenile Court of
Baltimore, and the address concerned the work of that court.
Dr. Harry emphasized especially
the success of the parole system in
preventing first offenders from
being forced into a career of crime..
About 100 students were present.

Additions to Museum.

Valuable articles have lately been
added to the Johns Hopkins University Museum. They are lent by
Dr. Esther B. Van Deman, research associate in Rome of the
Carnegie Institution of Washington,
who delivered a lecture in McCoy
Hall last week on "Master Builders
of Ancient Rome."
Among the numerous objects lent
to the museum should be mentioned
a'fine pair of Roman bronze cymbals, the only pair in this country,
and one of the very few examples
in any museum to have the connecting bronze chain still attached.
There are also two beautiful bronze
mirrors with incised designs of
great beauty; a magnificent cistrum,
such as the Egyptian priests of
Isis used in their processions in
Rome; a number of Roman glass
bottles and vases; an etruscan funeral urn, with a so far undecipherable inscription; several large early
Roman bronze coins, Roman lamps,
and pottery of various shapes.
There are besides, several bronze
bracelets and rings, and a number
of splendid bronze fibulae or safety
pins. There are also some fine
specimens of Roman marbles and
alabasters. These articles have been
put in one of the cases of the Archeological museum on the third
floor of McCoy Hall. Dr. Van Deman is the aunt of Dr. R. V. D.
Magoffin of the department of history.
There is a precedent at Kansas

course. This cheer leader, besides
leading the yells, invents color
schemes to be used at the games.

The third week of the freshman
gyirnasium contest has been completed and the Whites and the
Blues are as close as they ever
were. Although several hundred
points have been scored by each
division, the totals are only about
fifteen points apart. The Blues
seem to have the individual "stars,"
while the Whites have the team
work. However, first one side and
then the other is ahead, so that the
final outcome promises to be very
exciting.
Captain Steuart White (Whites)
set for his men a pace that would
soon have left the Blues far behind
if Captain Geo. Dorsey (Blues)
had not kept his team constantly
on the alert.
The ,latest news
from the field of battle is as follows:
Captain White—"We shall end
in a blaze of glory."
Captain Dorsey—"We shall end
• in a trail of sparks."
The results of the latest events
are:
Horse and rider — Won by
Wh ites.

—Won by Whites.

year—B. T. Ellis made 17.
